In this volume the older form “Pecham'' has been used in preference to the form “ Peckham,'' which, though generally adopted of recent years, is misleading. Pec- ham (Peccham) in the Middle Ages was used indiscri- minately for Peckbam (Kent and Surrey) and Patcham (Sussex). That the Franciscan Archbishop of Canter- bury took his name from the latter village is quite clear from a well-known passage in his Register (p. 902), where he speaks of his affection for the priory of LeweS, “in the neighbourhood of which we grew up from child- hood”. Patcham is close to LeweS‚ and in the thir- teenth century the prior and convent of Lewes held the advowson and some of the tithes of the church of Patcham‚ which in 1340 they had license to appropriate.1
